item.description:
Criteria: NO WHINING, COMPLAINING, ETC. This will be a an easily paced hike that will average book time.. All hikers must have cold weather gear and be experienced above treeline in winter conditions. All hikers must have map & compass skills along with being prepared to spend an emergency night out in the woods.

All attendees must read, understand and agree to the waiver/liability as outlined by this website.

Distance Time Elev
Change
Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude
starting at Champney Falls Trailhead 43° 59' 24" 71° 17' 57"
This heavily used trail runs from the Kancamagus Highway, at a
point 11.5 mi. from NH 16 in Conway.
0.07 mi 2 min +9 ft on Champney Falls Trail
0.07 mi 2 min +9 ft This heavily used trail runs from the Kancamagus Highway, to the
Piper Trail in the flat saddle between Chocorua and the Three
Sisters. Champney Falls is attractive, particularly when there is a
good flow of water, and the trail has moderate grades all the way.
Leaving the parking area, the trail soon crosses Twin Brook on
rocks (the footbridge here was severely damaged by a flood in
March 2011 and is unsafe to use), turns right, passes the junction,
where the Bolles Trail diverges right, and proceeds south with
easy grades, mostly on an old logging road, to Champney Brook.
to the junction of Bolles Trail 43° 59' 22" 71° 17' 53"
1.33 mi 55 min +477 ft on Champney Falls Trail
1.40 mi 57 min +486 ft There it swings right to avoid an abandoned section of trail along
the brook, then descends left and returns to the old road along the
brook. A loop path diverges left to Pitcher Falls and Champney
Falls, climbing steeply near the falls. Caution: Many of the ledges
in the area around the falls are very slippery; there have been
many serious accidents in this vicinity. The main trail passes a
restricted outlook to the north, and the loop path rejoins.
to the junction of Champney Falls loop 43° 58' 29" 71° 17' 08"
1.60 mi 1 hr 26 min +1268 ft on Champney Falls Trail
3.00 mi 2 hr 23 min +1754 ft The steady ascent continues. The trail passes a good outlook to
the north and reaches the first of several switchbacks, and the
Champney Falls Cutoff (also known as Middle Sister Cutoff)
diverges left toward Middle Sister.
to the junction of Middle Sister Cutoff 43° 57' 42" 71° 16' 29"
0.15 mi 9 min +163 ft on Champney Falls Trail
3.15 mi 2 hr 32 min +1917 ft Soon after this junction, the Champney Falls Trail reaches the
ledgy saddle—where there is an outlook on a side path to the
right—then passes the junction on the left with the Middle Sister
Trail.
to the junction of Middle Sister Trail 43° 57' 38" 71° 16' 24"
0.05 mi 2 min -3 ft on Champney Falls Trail
3.20 mi 2 hr 34 min +1915 ft In another 80 yd., the Champney Falls Trail ends at its junction
with the Piper Trail.
to the junction of Piper Trail 43° 57' 36" 71° 16' 25"
0.20 mi 8 min +29 ft on Piper Trail
3.40 mi 2 hr 42 min +1944 ft This heavily used trail to Chocorua from NH 16, first blazed by
Joshua Piper, begins behind Davies Campground and General
Store. It is one of the most heavily used trails in the White
Mountains. To reach the new trailhead parking area, drive in on
the dirt road to the right of the store (signs).
Then the West Side Trail (part of the original Liberty Trail bridle
path) enters on the right.
to the junction of West Side Trail 43° 57' 30" 71° 16' 30"
0.48 mi 22 min +208 ft on Piper Trail
3.88 mi 3 hr 4 min +2152 ft The Piper Trail soon emerges from the woods and, marked with
yellow paint, continues south along the ridge over open ledges,
with occasional scrambles. It swings right and climbs over a
rocky knob, then ascends to the junction with the Brook Trail
to the junction of Brook Trail 43° 57' 15" 71° 16' 25"
0.02 mi 2 min +60 ft on Piper Trail
3.90 mi 3 hr 6 min +2212 ft The trail climbs a rock gully to the summit.
to Mt Chocorua 43° 57' 16" 71° 16' 24"
0.02 mi 2 min -60 ft on Piper Trail
3.92 mi 3 hr 8 min +2152 ft The Piper Trail descends a rock gully to the junction with the
Brook Trail.
to the junction of Brook Trail 43° 57' 15" 71° 16' 25"
0.48 mi 22 min -208 ft on Piper Trail
2
Distance Time Elev
Change
Trail / Waypoint Latitude Longitude
4.40 mi 3 hr 30 min +1944 ft It descends over a rocky knob, swings left and continues north
along the ridge over open ledges marked with yellow paint, with
occasional scrambles. It then enters the woods.
to the junction of West Side Trail 43° 57' 30" 71° 16' 30"
0.20 mi 8 min -29 ft on Piper Trail
4.60 mi 3 hr 38 min +1915 ft Then the West Side Trail (part of the original Liberty Trail bridle
path) enters on the left.
to the junction of Champney Falls Trail 43° 57' 36" 71° 16' 25"
0.05 mi 2 min +3 ft on Champney Falls Trail
4.65 mi 3 hr 40 min +1917 ft The Champney Falls Trail leaves the Piper Trail.
to the junction of Middle Sister Trail 43° 57' 38" 71° 16' 24"
0.15 mi 9 min -163 ft on Champney Falls Trail
4.80 mi 3 hr 49 min +1754 ft It passes the junction on the right with the Middle Sister Trail in
the ledgy saddle, and soon passes a side path to an outlook on
the left.
to the junction of Middle Sister Cutoff 43° 57' 42" 71° 16' 29"
1.60 mi 1 hr 26 min -1268 ft on Champney Falls Trail
6.40 mi 5 hr 15 min +486 ft The Champney Falls Cutoff (also known as Middle Sister Cutoff)
diverges right toward Middle Sister, then the Champney Falls Trail
descends by switchbacks and passes a good outlook to the north,
and the steady descent continues.
to the junction of Champney Falls loop 43° 58' 29" 71° 17' 08"
1.33 mi 55 min -477 ft on Champney Falls Trail
7.73 mi 6 hr 10 min +9 ft The trail passes a restricted outlook to the north, and a loop path
exits right to Pitcher Falls and Champney Falls, descending
steeply near the falls. Caution: Many of the ledges in the area
around the falls are very slippery; there have been many serious
accidents in this vicinity. The loop path reenters the trail and
farther down, the main path swings left off the old road to avoid an
abandoned section of trail along the brook. The trail returns to the
old road and continues its descent.
to the junction of Bolles Trail 43° 59' 22" 71° 17' 53"
0.07 mi 2 min -9 ft on Champney Falls Trail
7.80 mi 6 hr 12 min 0 ft Keeping mostly to the old logging road, the trail follows Champney
Brook at easy grades. The Bolles Trail diverges left, and soon the
trail crosses Twin Brook on rocks (the footbridge here was
severely damaged by a flood in March 2011 and is unsafe to use)
and arrives at the parking area.
to Champney Falls Trailhead 43° 59' 24" 71° 17' 57"
This heavily used trail runs from the Kancamagus Highway, at a
point 11.5 mi. from NH 16 in Conway.
7.80 mi 6 hr 12 min 0 ft Totals

the dirt road to the right of the store (signs).
Then the West Side Trail (part of the original Liberty Trail bridle

to the junction of West Side Trail 43° 57' 30" 71° 16' 30"
0.48 mi 22 min +208 ft on Piper Trail
3.88 mi 3 hr 4 min +2152 ft The Piper Trail soon emerges from the woods and, marked with

with occasional scrambles. It swings right and climbs over a

item.how_to_find_us: WE WILL BE IN A SILVER FOUR DOOR LEGACY SUBARU
item.name: MT. Chocorua VIA CHAMPNEY FALLS TRAIL
